Privacy Against Agnostic Inference Attacks in Vertical Federated Learning

Morteza Varasteh
School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering, University of Essex, Colchester CO4 3SQ, UK
m.varasteh@essex.ac.uk
Abstract

A novel form of inference attack in vertical federated learning (VFL) is proposed, where two parties collaborate in training a machine learning (ML) model. Logistic regression is considered for the VFL model. One party, referred to as the active party, possesses the ground truth labels of the samples in the training phase, while the other, referred to as the passive party, only shares a separate set of features corresponding to these samples. It is shown that the active party can carry out inference attacks on both training and prediction phase samples by acquiring an ML model independently trained on the training samples available to them. This type of inference attack does not require the active party to be aware of the score of a specific sample, hence it is referred to as an agnostic inference attack. It is shown that utilizing the observed confidence scores during the prediction phase, before the time of the attack, can improve the performance of the active partyâ€™s autonomous model, and thus improve the quality of the agnostic inference attack. As a countermeasure, privacy-preserving schemes (PPSs) are proposed. While the proposed schemes preserve the utility of the VFL model, they systematically distort the VFL parameters corresponding to the passive partyâ€™s features. The level of the distortion imposed on the passive partyâ€™s parameters is adjustable, giving rise to a trade-off between privacy of the passive party and interpretabiliy of the VFL outcomes by the active party. The distortion level of the passive partyâ€™s parameters could be chosen carefully according to the privacy and interpretabiliy concerns of the passive and active parties, respectively, with the hope of keeping both parties (partially) satisfied. Finally, experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed attack and the PPSs.

I Introduction

The emergence of distributed machine learning (ML) techniques has been a game-changer in the way valuable information is obtained from raw data in various fields, such as computer vision, image recognition, financial services, and natural language processing. With the growing need for the utilization of distributed data to construct more accurate and advanced ML models, there has been a surge in demand in multiple sectors. To address the limitations of centralized ML models, including issues with data storage, excessive computations, security and privacy breaches, various distributed ML techniques have been proposed [1]. One such technique is federated learning (FL), which was introduced in [2]. In FL, two or more data-centers, known as parties, work together to train a shared ML model, thereby addressing the concerns of traditional centralized learning. This approach has gained widespread attention for its applications in real-life scenarios, such as in health systems [3, 4], keyboard prediction [5, 6], and e-commerce [7, 8].

Three types of Federated Learning (FL) are commonly studied in the literature, including Horizontal FL (HFL), Vertical FL (VFL), and Transfer FL. The distinction between these approaches lies in the manner in which data is partitioned and shared among parties. In HFL, each party holds a unique set of samples, but all parties share the same features [9]. On the other hand, VFL involves parties sharing the same samples, but each party trains and predicts collaboratively using a separate set of features [10]. As shown in Figure 1, an illustration of VFL is presented, where a bank and a FinTech company collaborate in training a classifier that will be used by the bank to approve or reject credit card applications. The bank, as the active party, holds the ground truth labels for the samples in the training set. Meanwhile, the FinTech company, as the passive party, contributes to the VFL process by sharing a distinct set of features pertaining to the samples.

After the VFL model is trained, both the bank and the FinTech company use it collaboratively to make predictions for new samples. To do this, each party inputs their corresponding features for each sample into the model. Typically, a third party known as the coordinator authority (CA) is involved in this collaboration during both the training and prediction phases. The CAâ€™s role during the prediction phase is to obtain the modelâ€™s outcome for new samples and share it with the active party when requested. The model output can be in the form of a confidence score, which is a probability vector representing the likelihood of each class, or a one-hot vector representing the output class label. Due to privacy concerns, the confidence score of a sample may be distorted before it is delivered to the active party, typically by providing a noisy or rounded version of the score. In the literature generally two scenarios are considered for this type of collaboration, namely white box and black box settings, where the active party is aware and unaware of the passive partyâ€™s parameters, respectively.

Focusing on the prediction phase, in [11], it has been demonstrated that when the exact form of the confidence scores are shared with the active party, there is a risk of the adversary (i.e. the active party) reconstructing the features of the passive party, which are considered private information. This can result in a privacy leak for the users, and therefore known as inference attack. The reconstruction is accurate when the number of unknown features, or the passive party features, is less than the number of classes. In [12] various approaches regarding improved inference attacks have been proposed that are based on solving an under-determined system of linear equations. In particular, it is shown that using methods that approximate the best worst case solution among feasible solutions can significantly improve the attack accuracy. Furthermore, as a defense mechanism, it has been shown in [12] that by transforming the passive features111For brevity, throughout the paper we use passive (active) features and passive (active) parameters instead of passive (active) partyâ€™s features and passive (active) partyâ€™s parameters, respectively. in a linear fashion and keeping the transformation mapping hidden from the active party, it is possible to preserve the modelâ€™s accuracy while reducing the privacy leakage, (i.e., higher mean squared error in reconstructing the passive features).

While previous works have studied inference attacks in the prediction phase using samples whose confidence scores (or a different version of them) are available at the active party, in this paper, under the white box setting, we focus on the privacy leakage of samples whose confidence scores are not yet available at the active party. This can include samples in the prediction phase for which no score has been requested by the active party, as well as samples used in the training phase to train the VFL model. Since the adversary is unaware of the confidence score of the attack target, we refer to this type of attack as an agnostic inference attack. Focusing on this type of privacy leakage, the main contributions of the paper are as follows.

  • â€¢

    The active party uses its available resources, i.e., the training data with only the active features, to reconstruct an independent classifier similar to the VFL model. This classifier is named the adversary model (AM). This is possible because the active party already has access to the ground truth labels of samples in the training set. The AM can be used for two purposes. First, as a means to estimate any sampleâ€™s confidence score and conduct inference attacks on the passive features using the methods introduced in [12]. The main aspect of this type of attack is that the adversary is agnostic to the confidence score or any other form of it corresponding to the attack target, hence putting all the training samples at risk of privacy leakage as well. Second, by comparing the sample-by-sample scores obtained from the AM and VFL model during the prediction phase, the active party can use the amount of score mismatch as a measure of the improvement in classification due to the VFL and decide whether to continue or stop requesting further collaborative predictions. This is particularly useful when the active party incurs a cost for each VFL model prediction made through CA.

  • â€¢

    Although the AM is primarily trained on the training samples, its ability to conduct an attack can be enhanced by taking into account the prediction samples and their associated confidence scores that have already been communicated to the active party. We consider two scenarios for delivering confidence scores: when they are delivered in their exact form and when their corresponding class labels are delivered to the active party. It is observed that incorporating both the confidence scores and their corresponding class labels leads to significant and subtle improvements in the effectiveness of an attack, respectively. Observing that any any other forms222Note that by â€œany other formâ€, we mean those which do not affect the accuracy. of confidence scores, such as noisy or rounded scores, can be transformed into their corresponding class labels and utilized in the training of the AM highlights the inadequacy of privacy-preserving schemes (PPSs) that only focus on protecting the confidence scores. This realization prompts a reconsideration of PPSs in the context of VFL, with the main focus on the model parameters rather than the confidence scores, which departs from black and white views in VFL settings.

  • â€¢

    We propose PPSs as a defense mechanism against agnostic inference attacks. The proposed schemes are designed to maintain the utility of the VFL model, i.e., delivering confidence scores in their exact form, while at the same time preventing adversaries from misusing the VFL collaboration. To that end, we design algorithms in a case-by-case fashion, where the parameters corresponding to passive features are distorted. The level of distortion applied to passive parameters is variable and determines the degree of privacy leakage of the passive party. That is, a higher level of distortion applied to passive parameters results in a lower degree of privacy compromise. This creates a trade-off between interpretability of the VFL parameters/outcomes by the active party and privacy concerns of the passive party. To address the privacy-interpretability (PI) trade-off, we aim to find a balance that satisfies the needs of both parties to the greatest extent possible, rather than completely shielding the passive party from view or completely obscuring the active partyâ€™s understanding of the parameters. Our goal is to strike a balance between these two competing demands and find a solution that partially meets the needs of both parties

The paper is structured as follows. In Section II, an explanation of the system model under study is provided. In Section III, the characteristics of the datasets utilized in this paper, as well as the model used for evaluating the results, are reviewed. Section IV is dedicated to the introduction of agnostic inference attack and is divided into three sub-sections. In Section IV-A, the necessary background information required to perform an inference attack is discussed. Subsequently, in Section IV-B, the procedure for obtaining and refining the AM is detailed, followed by a performance analysis of agnostic inference attack in Section IV-C. The proposed PPSs against agnostic inference attack are described in detail in Section V, which is further divided into two sub-sections. In Section V-A, the geometry of optimization algorithms with orthogonality constraints, specifically optimization over Stiefel manifolds, is reviewed to provide a better understanding of one of the proposed PPSs. Additionally, an overview of the concept of interpretability in the context of the present work is also provided. In Section V-B, the technical analysis of the proposed PPSs is presented. In Section VI, the experimental results are reported and discussed, along with a comprehensive evaluation of the performance of agnostic inference attack on real-world datasets under various scenarios and the performance of the proposed PPSs. The paper concludes in Section VII.

II System model

II-A Machine learning (ML)

An ML model is a function fğœ½:ğ’³â†’ğ’°:subscriptğ‘“ğœ½â†’ğ’³ğ’°f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{U} parameterized by the vector ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}, where ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} and ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U} denote the input and output spaces, respectively. In this paper, we consider the supervised classification setting, where a labeled training dataset is used to train the model.

Classification can be done by choosing the class that has the highest probability.

II-B Vertical Federated Learning

VFL is a type of distributive ML model training approach in which two or more parties are involved in the training process, such that they hold the same set of samples with disjoint set of features. The main goal in VFL is to train a model in a privacy-preserving manner, i.e., to collaboratively train a model without each party having access to other partiesâ€™ features. Typically, the training involves a trusted third party known as the CA, and it is commonly assumed that only one party has access to the label information in the training and testing datasets. This party is named active and the remaining parties are called passive. Throughout this paper, we assume that only two parties are involved; one is active and the other is passive. The active party is assumed to be honest but curious, i.e., it obeys the protocols exactly, but may try to infer passive features based on the information received. As a result, the active party is exchangeably referred to as the adversary in this paper.

In the existing VFL frameworks, CAâ€™s main task is to coordinate the learning process once it has been initiated by the active party. During the training, CA receives the intermediate model updates from each party, and after a set of computations, backpropagates each partyâ€™s gradient updates, separately and securely. To meet the privacy requirements of partiesâ€™ datasets, cryptographic techniques such as secure multi-party computation (SMC) [13] or homomorphic encryption (HE) [14] are used.

Once the global model is trained, upon the request of the active party for a new record prediction, each party computes the results of their model using their own features. CA aggregates these results from all the parties, obtains the prediction vector (confidence scores), and delivers that to the active party for further action. Throughout this paper, we assume that the active party is not allowed to make any query about the scores of the samples in the training set. This is justified due to the fact that the active party already has the ground truth labels of the training set. Note that there could be some edge cases where confidence scores of all the samples (both in the training and prediction phases) are required, such as when the active party aims at forming a soft clustering among all the samples via Gaussian mixture model to determine a high-confidence region within each class666For instance, in the Bank-FinTech example, the bank may wish to grant credit approval for clients with low entropy confidence scores due to budget limitations.. Where this is the case, i.e., exact or distorted versions of attack targetsâ€™ scores are available at the active party, inference attack methods studied in [12] could be applied to reconstruct the passive features.

As in [11, 12], we assume that the active party has no information whatsoever about the underlying distribution of passive features. However, it is assumed that the knowledge about the names, types and ranges of passive features is available to the active party to decide whether to participate in a VFL or not.

III Datasets and model

Datasets. In this paper, we perform a comprehensive evaluation of our proposed methods on five real-world and publicly available datasets, namely Bank, Adult salaries, Pen-based handwriting digits, Electrical grid stability and Satellite. These datasets have been widely used in the literature and have been obtained from the Machine Learning Repository website [15]. They have been selected to cover a wide range of classification tasks, including both binary and multi-class classification. The details of each of these datasets are provided in Table I. Furthermore, to gain further insights into the characteristics of these datasets, we provide a visual representation of some of their empirical statistics in Figure 3.

In the Bank dataset, there are a total of 20 features. However, as stated in the datasetâ€™s description file on the Machine Learning Repository website [15], the 11th feature has a significant impact on the output target and should be disregarded in order to obtain a more accurate predictive model. As a result, the training process in our study is based on 19 features, as detailed in Table I. Additionally, this dataset has 10 categorical features which need to be handled properly by the predictive model. Common ways to do this include one-hot encoding of the categorical features, mapping ordinal values to each category, mapping categorical values to theirs statistics, and so on. In this paper, we have chosen to map each categorical feature to its average within each class. This approach has been found to be effective for models such as Logistic Regression (LR) and Neural Networks (NN).

In our selection of datasets for the purpose of classification, we have considered a number of key factors. Firstly, it is crucial that the LR model performs reasonably well on the chosen dataset. Here, we have chosen the minimum 85% test accuracy as a threshold below which a dataset is discarded from the experiments. This is essential as any less reliable confidence scores produced by the LR model would make it difficult to demonstrate the impact of the agnostic inference attack. Secondly, it is necessary that each feature in the dataset contributes significantly to the training of the VFL model. If not, the matrices ğ•actsubscriptğ•act\mathbb{W}_{\text{act}} and ğ•passubscriptğ•pas\mathbb{W}_{\text{pas}} may contain small numbers associated with those features, leading to errors in the machineâ€™s calculations. This was avoided in our experiments by utilizing feature importance calculation methods. Thirdly, the dataset chosen should not have a diagonal covariance matrix associated to its features. As will be explained later, an agnostic inference attack on datasets with a diagonal covariance matrix does not result in a substantial breach of privacy. To further emphasize this point, we have included the Grid dataset as an example, in which we provide a clear explanation of why this type of attack is not effective on these types of datasets.

Model. In this paper, we focus on LR, which can be modelled as

ğœ=Ïƒâ€‹(ğ–ğ±+ğ›),ğœğœğ–ğ±ğ›\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{Wx}+\mathbf{b}), (2)

where ğ–ğ–\mathbf{W} and ğ›ğ›\mathbf{b} are the parameters collectively denoted as ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}, and Ïƒâ€‹(â‹…)ğœâ‹…\sigma(\cdot) is the sigmoid or softmax function in the case of binary or multi-class classification, respectively. Each party holds their parameters corresponding to their local features. The VFL model is trained in a centralized manner, which is a reasonable assumption according to [11]. It is assumed that no intermediate information is revealed during the training phase, and only the final model is disclosed.

As in [11], the feature values in each dataset are normalized into [0,1]01[0,1]. It is important to note that normalizing the entire dataset, including both the training and test data, may lead to an overly optimistic model accuracy, a phenomenon known as data snooping [16]. This effect occurs when working with very noisy datasets and should be avoided in such cases. However, in our experiments, we have not considered this issue as the datasets under consideration are not excessively noisy.

Each dataset has been divided into 80% training data and 20% prediction data. The training set which is the one used for VFL model training is again split into 80% training and 20% test data. Data splitting is done using train__\_test__\_split in the scikit-learn package. In training LR, we apply early stopping, and the training is done without considering any regularization. ADAM optimization is used for training, and the codes, which are in PyTorch, are available online in our GitHub repository [17].

Baselines. Depending on the number of unknown features compared to the number of classes in a dataset, two different scenarios are considered. To approach these cases we use two different inference attack (estimation) methods, namely the least square and halfâˆ— methods. The latter is proposed in [12] which is also briefly explained in section IV-A.

IV Agnostic Inference Attack

IV-A Preliminaries

Let (ğ˜T,ğ—T)Tsuperscriptsuperscriptğ˜ğ‘‡superscriptğ—ğ‘‡ğ‘‡(\mathbf{Y}^{T},\mathbf{X}^{T})^{T} denote random dtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡d_{t}-dimensional input samples, where the (dtâˆ’d)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘‘(d_{t}-d)-dimensional ğ˜ğ˜\mathbf{Y}, and the dğ‘‘d-dimensional ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X}, correspond to the feature values held by the active and passive parties, respectively. The white-box setting refers to the scenario where the adversary is aware of (ğ–act,ğ–pas,ğ›)subscriptğ–actsubscriptğ–pasğ›(\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}},\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}},\mathbf{b}) and the black-box setting refers to the context in which the adversary is only aware of ğ–actsubscriptğ–act\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}}. In this paper, we are interested in a scenario where the active party wishes to reconstruct passive features of samples whose confidence scores ğœğœ\mathbf{c} have not been observed yet (which encompasses all the samples in the training phase as well). One measure by which the attack performance can be evaluated is the mean squared error per feature, i.e.,

MSE=1dâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ—âˆ’ğ—^â€–2],MSE1ğ‘‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ—^ğ—2\textnormal{MSE}=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}\left[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}\|^{2}\right], (7)

where ğ—^^ğ—\hat{\mathbf{X}} is the adversaryâ€™s estimate. Let Nğ‘N denote the number of samples whose passive features have been estimated. Assuming that these Nğ‘N samples are produced in an i.i.d. manner, Law of Large Numbers (LLN) allows to approximate MSE by its empirical value 1Nâ€‹dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–ğ—iâˆ’ğ—i^â€–21ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptnormsubscriptğ—ğ‘–^subscriptğ—ğ‘–2\frac{1}{Nd}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\mathbf{X}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{X}_{i}}\|^{2}, since the latter converges almost surely to (7) as Nğ‘N grows.

IV-B Adversary Model (AM)

Recall that we study a scenario where prediction scores (exact forms or other) of attack targets are not available at the active party. When evaluating the potential inference attacks within this context, it is important to consider the passive partyâ€™s vulnerabilities due to not just the white box setting, but also the availability of data to the active party. This aspect of the scenario (the active partyâ€™s data) is often overlooked or underestimated in the related literature, but it can play a significant role in the success or failure of an attack. The active partyâ€™s access to data and the quality of that data can greatly impact their ability to carry out an effective inference attack. Despite the limitations imposed by the lack of access to prediction scores, the active party can still utilize the data and resources available to them to conduct an inference attack on passive features during both the training and prediction phases. To achieve this, the active party can build an independent AM using the training data at their disposal. This allows the active party to estimate the confidence scores of their target, empowering them to carry out a successful attack. To build an AM, the active party trains a classifier, denoted by fğœ½a:ğ’´â†’ğ’°:subscriptğ‘“subscriptğœ½ğ‘â†’ğ’´ğ’°f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}:\mathcal{Y}\to\mathcal{U}, using only the active features, independently of the passive party and CA. This is feasible as the active party already has the ground truth labels for their training set. The parameters of the AM are obtained through a training process applied over the active partyâ€™s dataset, via the following minimization

minğœ½aâ¡1ntâ€‹âˆ‘i=1ntHâ€‹(fğœ½aâ€‹(ğ²t,i),ui)+Ï‰â€‹(ğœ½a),subscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ»subscriptğ‘“subscriptğœ½ğ‘subscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğœ”subscriptğœ½ğ‘\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}\frac{1}{n_{t}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{t}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}),u_{i})+\omega(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}), (8)

where ntsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡n_{t} is the number of training samples, and ğ²t,isubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–\mathbf{y}_{t,i} is the active features of the iğ‘–i-th sample in the training set.

Training an independent classifier by the active party may appear to be a useful method to evaluate the improvement in performance due to collaboration with the passive party when building the VFL model. However, this approach can also be used for malicious purposes. For example, the active party can use fğœ½asubscriptğ‘“subscriptğœ½ğ‘f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}} to estimate confidence scores, denoted by ğœ^^ğœ\hat{\mathbf{c}}, without even making a prediction query from CA. These estimates can then be used to conduct inference attacks on passive features of any training or unseen sample. This can be achieved by forming a new set of equations using the steps outlined in (3) to (6), with ğœğœ\mathbf{c} being replaced with ğœ^^ğœ\hat{\mathbf{c}}. As discussed in further detail in section IV-C, with this new set of equations, the adversary can use known methods for inference attacks [12] to estimate the passive features. Needless to say that this puts all samples in the training set and samples whose scores have yet to be observed at risk of privacy breaches.

Postponing the technical analysis to section IV-C, in Figure 3 the performance of agnostic inference attack (solid line) on the bank dataset is compared with two other baselines, namely the half (green solid++ line) and halfâˆ— (blue solidâˆ™âˆ™\bullet line) estimations. In the former, the passive features are estimated as half (recall that features are normalized into [0,1]01[0,1]). In the latter, the halfâˆ— estimation method, proposed in [12], is used. As it is observed from the results in Figure 3, even in the absence of targetsâ€™ confidence scores, the adversary manages to conduct an inference attack comparably well, especially for larger values of dğ‘‘d where the difference with the normal inference attack is negligible.

IV-B1 Refined AM

To further enhance the accuracy of the AM in estimating the targetsâ€™ confidence scores, the active party can leverage the prediction scores received from CA before carrying out an inference attack on a specific target. These scores are generated by applying the VFL model that has been trained on the combination of both active and passive features. As a result, they carry a higher level of confidence compared to the scores generated from fğœ½asubscriptğ‘“subscriptğœ½ğ‘f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}. To take advantage of this increased reliability, the active party could adopt a training approach where the objective loss function incorporates the scores received from the CA. This can be done in a way that during the AM training, a higher cost is incurred in the event of a mismatch between the refined AMâ€™s scores and the scores received from CA.

We study two cases for this scenario: case i) when the confidence scores are delivered to the active party in their exact form, and case ii) when the class labels corresponding to the scores are provided instead. Itâ€™s important to note that as long as the delivered scores retain their accuracy, (at the very least) they can be converted into their corresponding class labels and utilized for refining the AM. Our experimental results indicate that refining the AM via confidence scores and class labels leads to pronounced and subtle improvement of an attack performance by the active party, respectively.

The refined AM, denoted as fğœ½arsubscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿf_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}, is trained on the active partyâ€™s available data by solving the following optimization problem

minğœ½arsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}\ \ 1nt+npâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1ntHâ€‹(fğœ½arâ€‹(ğ²t,i),ut,i)+Î²â€‹âˆ‘j=1npHâ€‹(fğœ½arâ€‹(ğ²p,j),up,j))1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ»subscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ»subscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ²ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘—\displaystyle\frac{1}{n_{t}+n_{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n_{t}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}),u_{t,i})+\beta\sum_{j=1}^{n_{p}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{p,j}),u_{p,j})\right)
+Î±npâ€‹âˆ‘j=1npSâ€‹(fğœ½arâ€‹(ğ²p,j),ğœj)+Ï‰â€‹(ğœ½ar)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘†subscriptğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ²ğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘—ğœ”superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha}{n_{p}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{p}}S\left(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{p,j}),\mathbf{c}_{j}\right)+\omega(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}) (9)

where npsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{p} denotes the total number of prediction samples (whose scores have already been delivered to the active party). The hyperparameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are used to stress the level of reliability of the prediction scores and the class labels, respectively obtained from CA as compared to the ones obtained by feeding the corresponding active features into AM. Additionally, the scoring function, Sâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦S(x,y), is defined as log2â¡(x/y)superscript2ğ‘¥ğ‘¦{\log^{2}(x/y)}.

Remark 1.

It is noted that when there is no prediction score available, the objective function in (IV-B1) is essentially the same as the one in (8). In scenarios where CA provides confidence scores in their exact form, the values of the hyperparameters (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta) are set to (1,0)10(1,0). This is because in this scenario, it is deemed unnecessary to utilize both the confidence scores and the corresponding class labels as the latter can be derived from the former. On the other hand, when only the class labels are utilized for refining AM, (Î±,Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½(\alpha,\beta) is set to (0,1)01(0,1). This is simply due to the unavailability of confidence scores at the active party in this case.

Remark 2.

The choice of the function Sâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)ğ‘†â‹…â‹…S(\cdot,\cdot) in equation (IV-B1) is motivated by the desire to model the similarity (or soft mismatch) between the confidence scores delivered by CA and the ones produced by AM. The function Sâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦S(x,y) is a quasiconvex888This function is not convex as, however, it is quasi-convex. A function is quasi-convex if its lower level sets are convex. function that attains its minimum value of zero when x=yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x=y. By setting Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1, one can adjust the significance of samples during the prediction phase. This is essentially equivalent to enforce AM to overfit over the prediction confidence scores received from CA.

Remark 3.

The values of the hyperparameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta in equation (IV-B1) must be determined by the active party without knowledge of the actual values of the passive features. Determining the optimal values of these hyperparameters requires a significant amount of numerical experimentation on a diverse range of data, and would require a substantial effort to reach a consensus through experimentation. We leave the further exploration of this matter to interested parties.

IV-C Performance Analysis

Upon agreement on a trained VFL model, during the prediction phase, the active party receives the corresponding confidence score (or a modified version of it, such as a noisy or rounded version, or the corresponding class label). In the white-box setting, the active party can construct a system of linear equations as described in equation (6), where the unknown variables are the passive features. If the number of unknowns, dğ‘‘d, is equal to or less than the number of equations, kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1, and the confidence scores are provided in their exact form, the active party can recover the passive features by solving the linear system, ğ€ğ—=ğ›â€²ğ€ğ—superscriptğ›â€²\mathbf{A}\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}. However, if the confidence scores have been altered to satisfy privacy requirements, or if the number of unknowns, dğ‘‘d, is greater than the number of equations, kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1, causing ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} to not have full column rank, there may exist either a different solution or an infinite number of solutions for the linear system, respectively.

A closer examination of (6) poses the following question: In a white box setting, to what extent does the lack of confidence scores from the attack targets contribute to the average reconstruction error in (7)? Or equivalently, can an inference attack still be performed effectively in the absence of the actual confidence score? In order to answer these questions, we will evaluate the performance of an attack when an estimate of a confidence score obtained from AM is used instead of the actual value. We will consider two scenarios: i) d<kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d<k, and ii) dâ‰¥kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d\geq k. These scenarios will be analyzed in detail to gain a better understanding of the impact of the absence of confidence scores.

IV-C1 d<kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d<k

In this case, we have an overdetermined system of linear equations, i.e., we have more equations (kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1) than unknowns (dğ‘‘d). An overdetermined system can have solutions in some cases, e.g., when some equations are linear combinations of others. In the context of this paper, an example of an overdetermined system with a unique solution is when the active party have all the ingredients needed to solve (6). In this case, no matter which dğ‘‘d equations are chosen out of kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1, it yields the same solution. However, depending on how many of the equations are independent of each other, we can have other cases with no solution or infinite solutions. The case of interest where the active party do not have the attack targetâ€™s confidence score, is an example of an overdetermined system with no solution. In this case, approximate solutions can be obtained via the method of ordinary least squares, i.e., minğ—â¡â€–ğ€ğ—âˆ’ğ›â€²^â€–subscriptğ—normğ€ğ—^superscriptğ›â€²\min_{\mathbf{X}}\|\mathbf{AX}-\hat{\mathbf{b}^{\prime}}\|, the solution of which can be written with the normal equations as999Throughout the paper, ğœ^â€²superscript^ğœâ€²\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime} is adversaryâ€™s estimation of ğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\mathbf{c}^{\prime}, and accordingly, ğ›^â€²superscript^ğ›â€²\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime} is an approximation of ğ›â€²superscriptğ›â€²\mathbf{b}^{\prime} induced by ğœ^â€²superscript^ğœâ€²\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}.

With (10), an approximate solution is found when no exact solution exists (ğ›^â€²â‰ ğ›â€²superscript^ğ›â€²superscriptğ›â€²\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime}\neq\mathbf{b}^{\prime}), and it gives an exact solution when one does exist101010To achieve good numerical accuracy, using QR factorization is recommended. (i.e., when ğ›^â€²=ğ›â€²superscript^ğ›â€²superscriptğ›â€²\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}).

IV-C2 dâ‰¥kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d\geq k

In the study presented in [12], several inference attack methods were evaluated, including RCC1, RCC2, CLS, and halfâˆ—. These methods were found to significantly improve the adversaryâ€™s estimation quality, resulting in lower MSE compared to the methods discussed in [11, 18]. While the results and discussions for agnostic inference attack in this paper are general and apply to any of the feature estimation methods, for the purposes of this paper, we specifically focus on using the halfâˆ— method. This is because, on the one hand, the halfâˆ— method is analytically feasible, making it easier to study. On the other hand, as indicated in [12, Figure 4], the halfâˆ— reconstruction method was found to have the best performance, or at least performance comparable to the best method. Thus, before proceeding with our analysis, we briefly outline the halfâˆ— estimation method.

Any solution of an underdetermined system of linear equations (dâ‰¥kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d\geq k) can be written as ğ€+â€‹ğ›â€²+(ğˆdâˆ’ğ€+â€‹ğ€)â€‹ğ°superscriptğ€superscriptğ›â€²subscriptğˆğ‘‘superscriptğ€ğ€ğ°\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{w} for some ğ°âˆˆâ„dğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where ğ€+superscriptğ€\mathbf{A}^{+} denotes the pseudoinverse of ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} satisfying the Moore-Penrose conditions[19]121212When ğ€ğ€\mathbf{A} has linearly independent rows, we have ğ€+=ğ€Tâ€‹(ğ€ğ€T)âˆ’1superscriptğ€superscriptğ€ğ‘‡superscriptsuperscriptğ€ğ€ğ‘‡1\mathbf{A}^{+}=\mathbf{A}^{T}(\mathbf{AA}^{T})^{-1}.. As elaborated further in [12], when the only available information about ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} is that it belongs to [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d}, then ğ—^half=12â€‹ğŸdsubscript^ğ—half12subscript1ğ‘‘\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}=\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d} is optimal in the best-worst sense. Indeed, the naive estimate of 12â€‹ğŸd12subscript1ğ‘‘\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}, is the Chebyshev center of [0,1]dsuperscript01ğ‘‘[0,1]^{d}. The adversary can perform better when the side information (ğ›â€²,ğ€)superscriptğ›â€²ğ€(\mathbf{b}^{\prime},\mathbf{A}) is available. The halfâˆ— scheme is built on top of the naive 12â€‹ğŸd12subscript1ğ‘‘\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d} estimation as follows. The estimator finds a solution in the solution space that is closest to 12â€‹ğŸd12subscript1ğ‘‘\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}. In [12, Proposition 1] it is shown that

where the third term in (19]) is 00 due to ğ€+Tâ€‹(ğˆâˆ’ğ€+â€‹ğ€)=ğŸsuperscriptsuperscriptğ€ğ‘‡ğˆsuperscriptğ€ğ€0{\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})=\mathbf{0}. The first term in (20]) is due to [12, Theorem 2]. From (21) it is clear that the adversaryâ€™s ability to carry out agnostic inference attack is dependent on the accuracy of the estimation of a target confidence score, as reflected through the term ğŠğœâ€²,ğœ^â€²subscriptğŠsuperscriptğœâ€²superscript^ğœâ€²\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c}^{\prime},\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}}. It is important to note that the second term in (18) is always positive, resulting in a positive value for the second term in (21). Therefore, the adversaryâ€™s performance in this scenario cannot surpass the performance obtained when the exact form of confidence scores is known. However, neither the active party nor the passive party have access to the exact form of the confidence scores or the parameters of AM, respectively, making it impossible for them to determine the exact value of (18). Despite this, we utilize (21) in section VI to obtain our numerical results when evaluating the adversaryâ€™s performance.

It is worth mentioning here that the replacement of ğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\mathbf{c}^{\prime} with ğœâ€²^^superscriptğœâ€²\hat{\mathbf{c}^{\prime}} in 6 may result in some components of the final solution falling outside of the feasible region. To handle such cases, there are multiple strategies that can be implemented, including but not limited to: i) Mapping the individual components of the solution to the closest value of 0 or 1 if they are outside of the feasible region, ii) Mapping those individual components to the value of 0.5, or iii) Mapping all the passive features to 0.5 once an estimated feature of a sample falls outside the feasible region. It is important to note that the selection of the best strategy depends on the underlying data statistics and requires deeper knowledge of the data which is indeed not available at the active party. Therefore, in order to ensure fairness in our numerical results, this paper adopts the first strategy in all datasets used in our experiments.

Remark 4.

It is worth mentioning that while halfâˆ— was initially proposed for LR models [12], it can also be adapted for feed forward Neural Networks (NNs). This can be achieved by considering each layer of a NN as a separate LR model and applying halfâˆ— layer by layer, until the estimate of the NNâ€™s input is obtained. While it is possible that the results presented in this paper could be extended to NN models using this approach, we leave the confirmation of this claim for future research, where a thorough investigation of the effectiveness of halfâˆ— in NN models is conducted.

V Privacy against agnostic inference attack

In the literature a number of algorithms have been proposed for privacy in the context of VFL in the white box setting, such as those proposed in [11, 18, 12]. The majority of these algorithms have attempted to alter the confidence scores delivered to the active party in some way. However, as demonstrated in Figure 3 and discussed in section IV, simply modifying the confidence scores is not enough to defend against agnostic inference attacks, where the adversary can build a separate classifier and improve their attack as they collect more scores from the CA. As such, it becomes clear that this approach is insufficient and leaves the passive party vulnerable to such attacks.

The central importance of the passive partyâ€™s parameters in any potential adversarial attack highlights the need for effective defense techniques that specifically target these parameters. A straightforward approach would be to implement a black box setting, in which the active party is not privy to the passive partyâ€™s parameters, ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}. However, this approach sacrifices interpretability of the VFL model, which is a critical aspect in many applications where the client or user demands a clear explanation for the decisions made by the machine. This creates a tension between the active party, who desires a white box setting for interpretability purposes, and the passive party, who values privacy and prefers a black box setting. Therefore, there is a pressing need for a more nuanced and balanced approach to designing PPSs in the context of VFL, one that strikes a delicate balance between privacy and interpretability, and minimizes the cost of collaboration for all involved parties. The following sections present an effort towards realizing this elusive goal of balancing privacy and interpretability in VFL.

The question we aim to address is: Can a PPS be designed that creates a balance between preserving the privacy of the passive party and enabling the interpretability capabilities of the active party? To achieve this, we take into account the potential for agnostic inference attacks by an adversary using either (11) or (16) in different scenarios. Our proposed PPSs aim to systematically manipulate the parameters ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} in order to partially address the concerns of both parties and provide a mutually acceptable outcome.

In the following, in subsection V-A, we first review a particular case of optimization algorithms. Additionally, we provide an informal discussion on interpretability of parameters in LR. Then, in section V-B, in a case-by-case fashion, we cover the technical analysis of the proposed PPSs.

V-A Preliminaries

V-A1 Optimization problems with orthogonality constraint

Here, we provide a brief overview of an algorithm employed in this paper to determine the well-performing design parameters of one of the proposed PPSs. This algorithm is a specific instance of a larger class of optimization problems that incorporate an orthogonality constraint, specifically optimization problems over Stiefel manifolds. While this particular case is reviewed in the sequel, for a more in-depth and comprehensive understanding of the geometry of the problem and the solver algorithms, we refer the readers to [20] and [21, 22], respectively.

Consider the following optimization problem with an orthogonality constraint:

minğ‘:ğ‘Tâ€‹ğ‘=ğˆdfâ€‹(ğ‘),subscript:ğ‘absentsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğˆğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{R}:\\ \mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I}_{d}\end{subarray}}\ \ f(\mathbf{R}), (22)

where f:â„dÃ—dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} satisfies the so-called blanket assumption, i.e., the function fâ€‹(ğ‘)ğ‘“ğ‘f(\mathbf{R}) is differentiable and âˆ‚fâˆ‚ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}} is Lipschitz continuous131313Assume two metric spaces (ğ“¡,dğ‘)ğ“¡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}},d_{\mathbf{R}}) and (ğ’³,dâ€‹x)ğ’³ğ‘‘ğ‘¥(\mathcal{X},dx), where dğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{\mathbf{R}} and dâ€‹xğ‘‘ğ‘¥dx denote the metrics on ğ“¡ğ“¡\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}} and ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, respectively. A function f:ğ“¡â†’ğ’³:ğ‘“â†’ğ“¡ğ’³f:\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}}\rightarrow\mathcal{X} is called Lipschitz continuous if there exists a real constant Kâ‰¥0ğ¾0K\geq 0, such that for all ğ‘1subscriptğ‘1\mathbf{R}_{1} and ğ‘2subscriptğ‘2\mathbf{R}_{2} in ğ“¡ğ“¡\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}}, we have dxâ€‹(fâ€‹(ğ‘1),fâ€‹(ğ‘2))â‰¤Kâ‹…dğ‘â€‹(ğ‘1,ğ‘2)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘“subscriptğ‘1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘2â‹…ğ¾subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2d_{x}(f(\mathbf{R}_{1}),f(\mathbf{R}_{2}))\leq K\cdot d_{\mathbf{R}}(\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}) .. The orthogonality constraint in (22) can be expressed as ğ’®d={ğ‘âˆˆâ„dÃ—d|ğ‘Tâ€‹ğ‘=ğˆd}subscriptğ’®ğ‘‘conditional-setğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğˆğ‘‘\mathcal{S}_{d}=\{\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}|\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I}_{d}\}, and is denoted as Stiefel manifold in real matrix space.

Remark 5.

The problem outlined in equation (22) plays a crucial role in various applications, such as â€œdiscretized Kohn-Sham energy minimizationâ€ and â€œunsupervised feature selection.â€ There are numerous methods available to address this problem, the majority of which utilize a trust-region strategy with quadratic approximation. However, preserving feasibility often requires the use of an orthonormalization process, which can lead to low scalability, particularly when the number of columns is substantial. Thus, it is essential to employ an efficient approach that maintains the structure of the orthogonality constraints when solving (22). In our numerical experiments, we utilize the PySTOP module, which has been implemented in Python based on the methods described in [21, 22].

Almost all the algorithms tackling problems of the type (22), require gradient of the objective function fâ€‹(ğ‘)ğ‘“ğ‘f(\mathbf{R}) wrt the set ğ’®dsubscriptğ’®ğ‘‘\mathcal{S}_{d}. Denoting this gradient by âˆ‡sfâ€‹(ğ‘)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R}), it is shown in [20, eq. (2.53)], that it is of the form

âˆ‡sfâ€‹(ğ‘)=âˆ‚fâˆ‚ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘â€‹(âˆ‚fâˆ‚ğ‘)Tâ€‹ğ‘.subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R})=\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}}-\mathbf{R}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}}\right)^{T}\mathbf{R}. (23)

One can view (23) as correcting the nominal gradient âˆ‚fâˆ‚ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}} by subtracting off its project, i.e., (âˆ‚fâˆ‚ğ‘)Tâ€‹ğ‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘(\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}})^{T}\mathbf{R} onto the current solution ğ‘ğ‘\mathbf{R}. This ensures that the corrected gradient âˆ‡sfâ€‹(ğ‘)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R}) is tangent to the manifold.

In the following, we provide an analytically tractable example of this optimization (22) in the context of PPSs in VFL. As it will be elaborated later in section V-B, providing analytical solutions for more interesting problems are still open if not infeasible. Therefore, in such cases we resort to iterative solver algorithms.

=Â±Trâ€‹(ğ”â€‹ğšºâ€‹ğ”T)=Â±âˆ‘i=1dÏƒi,absentplus-or-minusTrğ”ğšºsuperscriptğ”ğ‘‡plus-or-minussuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptğœğ‘–\displaystyle=\pm\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{U}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{U}^{T})=\pm\sum_{i=1}^{d}\sigma_{i}, (32)

where Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} is the i-th singular value of ğ€+â€‹ğ€ğŠğŸsuperscriptğ€subscriptğ€ğŠ0\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{0}}. Noting that the singular values of a matrix are non-negative, the minimiser of (29) is ğ‘=âˆ’ğ”ğ•Tğ‘superscriptğ”ğ•ğ‘‡\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{UV}^{T}.

Remark 6.

A similar problem has been considered in [12, Theorem 3], where instead of transforming the parameters, the passive party transforms the features. In that study, the proof approach relies on Von Neumannâ€™s trace inequality, which can serve as an alternative to the optimization over Stiefel manifolds discussed in this paper. However, as will be made evident in the following sections, the optimization over Stiefel manifolds has a distinct advantage in that it allows for the treatment of a wide range of more complex problems through the use of iterative algorithms.

Remark 7.

It is worth noting that the example discussed in this section has a couple of limitations. Firstly, the assumption that the adversary will use the least square method is unrealistic as there are other inference attack methods that are more advanced and efficient. Secondly, transforming the parameter or feature space, as discussed in [12, Theorem 3, Remark 6]), results in a significant and uncontrolled distortion of the parameters. This can make it difficult for the active party to interpret the results of the VFL model, and may even obstruct their ability to justify the outcomes in certain circumstances. For example, in the Bank-FinTech scenario, the bank may be required to provide a justification for rejecting a customerâ€™s credit card application. Thus, it is crucial that these limitations are taken into consideration when designing any PPS so as to ensure the active partyâ€™s concerns are addressed.

V-A2 Interpretability of the VFL model at the active party

The widespread adoption of machine learning-based automation systems in various sectors of society, including governments, banking, healthcare, and education, has become increasingly common. Although these systems bring many operational benefits, there are also important challenges that need to be addressed. One such challenge in the context of VFL is the interpretability of machine-based decisions when passive parties participate in the training of VFL using PPSs. This becomes particularly relevant in cases where VFL models are used to make decisions that have legal, insurance, or health implications, as a lack of justifiability of the outcomes can potentially harm the trust relationship between users and the system.

Interpretability is an essential aspect of machine learning models and refers to the ability to understand the relationship between the parameters of the model and its outcomes. Simple machine learning models such as linear and logistic regression, decision trees, and Lasso/Ridge regression are generally preferred over more complex deep learning models when performance levels are comparable, as they offer greater interpretability. For example, in the case of logistic regression, the odds ratio of two different classes for a sample can be easily calculated as e(ğ°iâˆ’ğ°j)â€‹ğ±1superscriptğ‘’subscriptğ°ğ‘–subscriptğ°ğ‘—subscriptğ±1e^{(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j})\mathbf{x}_{1}}, where ğ°isubscriptğ°ğ‘–\mathbf{w}_{i} is the iğ‘–i-th row of the parameter matrix [ğ–act,ğ–pas]subscriptğ–actsubscriptğ–pas[\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}},\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}]. Consider the Bank-FinTech example, where two customers ğ±1subscriptğ±1\mathbf{x}_{1} and ğ±2subscriptğ±2\mathbf{x}_{2} have similar active features but different passive features and one of them is approved for a credit card application while the other is rejected. If the customer ğ±1subscriptğ±1\mathbf{x}_{1} objects to the rejection, the bank must be able to justify the decision based on the difference in the passive feature and the corresponding change in the odds ratio, e(wâ€‹i,dtâˆ’wâ€‹j,dt)â€‹(x1,dtâˆ’x2,dt)superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¤ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡e^{(w{i,d_{t}}-w{j,d_{t}})(x_{1,d_{t}}-x_{2,d_{t}})}, where the subscript dtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡d_{t} refers to the index of the passive feature.

V-B Privacy-preserving schemes

When evaluating the effectiveness of agnostic inference attacks, we take a â€œgenie-aidedâ€ approach in which the adversary is given the exact form of the confidence scores. This is because the performance of the agnostic inference attacks in (13) and (21) is heavily dependent on the matrix ğŠğœ,ğœ^â€²subscriptğŠğœsuperscript^ğœâ€²\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c},\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}}. Since the passive party does not have access to ğœ^â€²superscript^ğœâ€²\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}, it is impossible to make accurate calculations based on it. By assuming a genie-aided scenario, we acknowledge that the adversary may have the resources and capacity (whether through their own data and computational power or through collusion/collaboration with some data owners as per [11]) to estimate ğœ^â€²superscript^ğœâ€²\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime} accurately. Thus, our goal is to diminish the adversaryâ€™s best-case attack performance under these circumstances. It is therefore in the benefit of the passive party to design privacy-preserving techniques based on the availability of ğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\mathbf{c}^{\prime} at the active party in order to maximize privacy protection.

In designing the proposed PPSs, our goal is to additionally keep the the passive parameters as much interpretable as possible. To that end, we consider the function

g=1dâ€‹kTr((ğ–pasâˆ’ğ–n)T(ğ–pasâˆ’ğ–n)g=\frac{1}{dk}\textnormal{Tr}((\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\mathbf{W}_{n})^{T}(\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\mathbf{W}_{n}) (33)

as a measure of distance between ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} and ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}, where ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} is the parameter set the active party is given access to instead of ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}171717The function gğ‘”g will take different arguments in the sequel depending of what mapping is considered from ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} to ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} ..

Remark 8.

Note that the way the adversary obtains a system of linear equations in (6) is not unique, however, all of these linear systems can be expressed similar to (6) via ğ‰new=ğ“ğ‰subscriptğ‰newğ“ğ‰\mathbf{J}_{\textnormal{new}}=\mathbf{TJ} with ğ“(kâˆ’1)Ã—(kâˆ’1)subscriptğ“ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜1\mathbf{T}_{(k-1)\times(k-1)} being an invertible matrix, (secretly) used by the adversary. From this standpoint, it is critical that regardless of the choice of ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}, the MSE in (38) on which the optimization in (39) is performed is the same MSE that the adversary experiences. Therefore, any proposed/designed privacy-preserving scheme should be independent of any transformation matrix ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T} used by the adversary, as otherwise, intended privacy (certain MSE) and interpretaibility (gâ€‹(ğ‘)=Ïµğ‘”ğ‘italic-Ïµg(\mathbf{R})=\epsilon) concerns are not guaranteed. From the objective function in (39), independence of gâ€‹(ğ‘)ğ‘”ğ‘g(\mathbf{R}) is obvious. Therefore, the solution of the objective function is independent of any orthogonal transformation of ğ‰ğ‰\mathbf{J}.

If the blanket assumption is satisfied on the objective of the problem in (39), it fits within the category of the optimization problems reviewed in section V-A. Continuity is obvious. The following proposition ascertains the Lipschitz continuity.

Proposition 1.

The objective function in (39) is Lipschitz continuous.

Remark 9.

The privacy-preserving scheme proposed in this case is based on the halfâˆ— estimation method. The reason for choosing this method is that designing a defense mechanism against one of the most powerful inference attack techniques would likely have a negative impact on the performance of other attack techniques. The exact impact on the performance of other techniques has not been analyzed in this study. We leave the technical analysis of this matter for interested researchers.

Remark 10.

It is important to note that when the active party has no privacy concerns, it would be clear to them that the transformation matrix is ğ‘=âˆ’ğˆğ‘ğˆ\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{I}. However, a dishonest active party may as well pretend that they have no interest in the interpretation of the results. In either case, they could easily recover the passive partyâ€™s features by changing the sign of the parameters. One potential solution to address this issue is to keep the active party uncertain about whether ğ‘=ğˆğ‘ğˆ\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I} or ğ‘=âˆ’ğˆğ‘ğˆ\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{I} was used for the parameter mapping. In this scenario, even if the adversary takes the average of the estimations obtained from both cases, the convexity of MSE would prevent them from obtaining an estimation error lower than the average of the MSE in each case. Another approach to preserving privacy would be to choose a random value for Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and transform the parameters accordingly without revealing the value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon to the active party.

Remark 12.

The problem in (50) is a simple vector-based optimization problem which is solved using algorithms, such as â€œtrust-region constrainedâ€ or â€œsequential least squares programmingâ€. In our numerical experiments, we use the former using Scipy package in python. Observe that when the equality constraint in (50) is replaced with inequality, and for larger values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, there can be possibly an infinite number of solutions for (50) that result in ğ€nTâ€‹ğ€n=ğ°ğ§ğ“â€‹ğ‰ğ“â€‹ğ‰ğ°ğ§=0superscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘›ğ‘‡subscriptğ€ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ§ğ“superscriptğ‰ğ“subscriptğ‰ğ°ğ§0\mathbf{A}_{n}^{T}\mathbf{A}_{n}=\mathbf{\mathbf{w}_{n}^{T}\mathbf{J}^{T}\mathbf{J}\mathbf{w_{n}}}=0. This could be the case for vectors with equal components that are in the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-vicinity of ğ°passubscriptğ°pas\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}. Considering equality constraint, significantly affects the demanding task of discarding such solutions.

Remark 13.

An interesting observation here is that, in the case of d=1ğ‘‘1d=1, the PPS does not depend on the statistics of the data. This rather undermines the idea of preserving passive partyâ€™s privacy as the active party can easily follow the same steps to solve (50). To overcome this situation, guidelines provided in Remark 10 could be applied. That is, either the passive party will not remain honest in revealing whether a PPS is in place, or they choose a random and secret 0â‰¤Ïµâ€²â‰¤Ïµ0superscriptitalic-Ïµâ€²italic-Ïµ0\leq\epsilon^{\prime}\leq\epsilon.

Remark 14.

In this scenario, any transformation of the parameters similar to previous cases (ğ‘âˆˆâ„ğ‘â„\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R} is a scalar) would result in scaling all the parameters by a constant factor, meaning ğ°n=râ€‹ğ°passubscriptğ°ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ°pas\mathbf{w}_{n}=r\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}. This ensures that the system of equations established by the adversary remains as an overdetermined system with a unique solution. Consequently, no matter which component of ğ°nsubscriptğ°ğ‘›\mathbf{w}_{n} the adversary selects, the attack equation would take the form wn,iâ€‹x=râ€‹wpas,iâ€‹x=biâ€²subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¤pas,iğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²w_{n,i}x=rw_{\textnormal{pas,i}}x=b_{i}^{\prime}, where wn,isubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›ğ‘–w_{n,i}, wpas, isubscriptğ‘¤pas, iw_{\textnormal{pas, i}} and biâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²b_{i}^{\prime} are the iğ‘–i-th components of ğ°nsubscriptğ°ğ‘›\mathbf{w}_{n}, ğ°passubscriptğ°pas\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}} and ğ›â€²superscriptğ›â€²\mathbf{b}^{\prime}, respectively. It is obvious that, in this case, not only a fixed scaling but any linear transformation of the parameters (which results in an overdetermined system with no solution) cannot keep the parameters secret indefinitely. As discussed in [12, section VI], the active party can collect valuable statistical information from received confidence scores (if the exact forms are provided) over time, which could be used to estimate the actual values of the parameters.

Remark 15.

The optimization problems in (50) and (54) for d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 and k=2ğ‘˜2k=2, respectively, are more general compared to the transforming matrices proposed in cases i and ii. Nevertheless, these approaches not only offer the potential to find better solutions when they are feasible, but also provide valuable insights into how far the designs proposed for cases i and ii are from the more general solutions (when both cases are applicable on a dataset).

VI Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of adversaryâ€™s inference attack on passive features according to the different setups proposed in the previous sections. The performance of inference attacks and PPSs are evaluated according to the MSE per feature in (7), which can be estimated empirically by 1Nâ€‹dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–ğ—iâˆ’ğ—^iâ€–21ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptnormsubscriptğ—ğ‘–subscript^ğ—ğ‘–2\frac{1}{Nd}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\mathbf{X}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{i}\|^{2} with Nğ‘N denoting the number of samples under study and dğ‘‘d denoting the number of passive features. Since agnostic inference attack can be applied on samples both in the training and prediction phase, we set N=nt+npğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘N=n_{t}+n_{p} for each dataset, and name this averaging over Nğ‘N as average over time. This is to distinguish from another type of averaging, namely, average over space, which is explained via an example as follows. Assume that the Bank data, which has 19 features, is considered. Also, consider the case that we are interested in obtaining the MSE when the active and passive parties have 14 and 5 features, respectively. Since these 19 features are not i.i.d., the MSE depends on which 5 (out of 19) features are allocated to the passive party. In order to resolve this issue, we average the MSE over some different possibilities of allocating 5 features to the passive party. More specifically, we average the MSE over a moving window of size 5 features, i.e., MSE is obtained for 19 scenarios where the feature indices of the passive party are [1:5],[2:6],[3:7],â€¦,{19}âˆª[1:4][1:5],[2:6],[3:7],\ldots,\{19\}\cup[1:4]. Afterwards, these 19 MSEâ€™s are summed and divided by 19, which denotes the MSE when d=5ğ‘‘5d=5.

In the following, in section VI-A, we first review the experimental results related to the agnostic inference attack studied in this paper. Then, in section VI-B, we focus on the performance of the proposed PPSs against this type of attack.

VI-A Experimental results on agnostic inference attack

In Figure 4, the resulted MSE from agnostic inference attack via AM (orange solid line denoted by AM) and refined AM (green solid+\boldsymbol{+} line denoted by RAMnp,Î±,Î²subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ›¼ğ›½{}_{n_{p},\alpha,\beta}) are compared with halfâˆ— estimation via VFL model (blue solidâˆ™âˆ™\bullet line denoted by VFL) and half estimation (red solidâ‹†bold-â‹†\boldsymbol{\star} line) for four different datasets. AM is trained based on the loss function defined in (8) using the training dataset available at the active party, while RAM is trained based on the loss function defined in (IV-B1) with the addition of np=100subscriptğ‘›ğ‘100n_{p}=100 confidence scores in their exact form received from CA. The RAM in this figure is according to the parameters (Î±,Î²)=(1,0)ğ›¼ğ›½10(\alpha,\beta)=(1,0) as defined in (IV-B1). As this is an evaluation for agnostic attacks, the MSE is calculated by considering both the training and prediction samples. It should be noted that since the scores obtained from AM are estimated values of the scores obtained from the VFL model, it is possible that even in the case of d<kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d<k, the estimated passive features are outside the feasible region (for d>kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d>k, the system is underdetermined and there is no guarantee that the solution will be in the feasible region). In such cases, the individual features that are outside the feasible region are mapped to either 0 or 1, whichever is closest. For the half estimation, all the passive features are estimated as half. The results show that even without the exact values of the targetâ€™s confidence scores, it is still possible to achieve a good performance on the inference attack using AM. For the bank, satellite, and adult datasets, the attack performance using AM is close to the halfâˆ— method via the VFL model in which the adversary has access to the exact values of the targetâ€™s confidence scores. Moreover, refining AM using (IV-B1) with only 100 scores significantly improves the attack performance, especially when the number of passive features is small. This is mainly because the active party has the advantage of a richer dataset (dtâˆ’d>dsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘‘d_{t}-d>d). Finally, while the attack using AM is not effective for the pendigit dataset, the attack using RAM significantly improves the performance.

In Figure 5, performance of agnostic inference attack for satellite dateset when the adversary obtains the estimated confidence scores via AM (orange solid), RAM using 50 prediction confidence scores (green solid++) and RAM using 100 prediction confidence scores (red solidâ‹…â‹…\cdot) are compared with half estimation and halfâˆ— via the VFL model. It can be seen that incorporating more confidence scores during the refinement process of AM prior to the attack improves the attack performance. The results show that even using as few as 50 confidence scores can still lead to a significant improvement in the attack performance when the number of passive features is low.

It is noted that the attack improvement achieved with RAM is observed on all the datasets examined in this paper, however for the sake of conciseness, only the one with the most significant improvements is illustrated. Additionally, the results indicate that even if a PPS is applied on the delivered confidence scores, the adversary (at the very least) extract the corresponding class labels and utilize them to refine AM (however slightly) via (IV-B1) with (Î±,Î²)=(0,1)ğ›¼ğ›½01(\alpha,\beta)=(0,1).

Remark 17.

The experimental results in this section demonstrate that while the use of confidence scores by the active party can certainly enhance the performance of the inference attack, it is the presence of passive parameters that offers the initial opportunity for exploiting the passive features. It is important to note that tampering with either the confidence scores or the passive parameters can have adverse effects on either the accuracy of the decisions or the interpretability of the results, respectively. In many scenarios, it may be considered more crucial to maintain accuracy in decision-making than the interpretability of the outcomes. Furthermore, as it will be clearer in section VI-B, for some cases, a small perturbation of the passive parameters can result in a significant improvement in preserving privacy while still allowing for some level of interpretability in the VFL model and keeping decisions accurate (delivering the confidence scores in the clear).

The results shown in Figure 4 reveal that the effectiveness of an agnostic inference attack is highly dependent on the nature of the data. For instance, it can be seen that an attack on the bank and adult datasets results in a higher gain compared to the pendigit dataset. This leads to the question of under what conditions the adversary can achieve a lower MSE through this type of inference attack.

To address this question, we can consider an ideal scenario in which the features of a dataset are mutually independent. In this scenario, training a classifier on one set of features would not reveal any information about the other set of features, thus rendering the inference attack infeasible. However, in real-world situations, there is always a degree of dependency among the features of a dataset.

Due to lack of technical tools to measure the dependency of two or more random variables directly, instead, here we use covariance of the features of a dataset as a an indirect metric. This is represented by the heat map of the covariance matrix ğŠğsubscriptğŠğ\mathbf{K}_{\boldsymbol{\mu}} shown in Figure 6. This matrix is calculated as ğŠğâ‰œğ”¼â€‹[(ğ—âˆ’ğ)â€‹(ğ—âˆ’ğ)T]â‰œsubscriptğŠğğ”¼delimited-[]ğ—ğsuperscriptğ—ğğ‘‡\mathbf{K}_{\boldsymbol{\mu}}\triangleq\mathds{E}[(\mathbf{X}-\boldsymbol{\mu})(\mathbf{X}-\boldsymbol{\mu})^{T}], where ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} is a dtsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘¡d_{t}-dimensional vector that represents the features and ğğ\boldsymbol{\mu} is the mean vector.

It can be observed that for the grid dataset, the corresponding covariance matrix is nearly diagonal, indicating that the features are nearly uncorrelated. As shown in Figure 7, the agnostic inference attack on this dataset is ineffective as it is almost similar to estimating the features as half. Furthermore, it can be seen from Figure 5 that the pendigit dataset has a covariance matrix that is more diagonal compared to the other three datasets (satellite, bank, adult), and its resistance to the agnostic inference attack is higher as a result.

Remark 18.

Figure 8 presents the average model accuracy of AM versus the number of active features in the datasets listed in Table I. The results show that the active party benefits more from VFL in the grid and pendigits datasets compared to the bank, satellite and adult datasets. This is because as the number of active features increases, the active party can achieve higher accuracy on the grid and pendigit datasets. The results from Figure 8 in conjunction with the results from Figures 4, 6 and 7 suggest that datasets that are more suitable for VFL collaboration and result in higher accuracy from VFL collaboration are less susceptible to agnostic inference attacks. This is a crucial aspect to consider for the active party when deciding to participate in a VFL collaboration, especially if the active party incurs costs for both VFL training and prediction. Overall, these results highlight the importance of understanding the relationship between VFL collaboration, decision accuracy, model interpretability and the vulnerability to inference attacks when considering participation in a VFL collaboration.

VI-B Experimental results on privacy-preserving schemes

In this section, we evaluate the effectiveness of the PPSs introduced in section V. Our assessment consists of two stages: first, we analyze each of the cases studied in section V-B separately by keeping either dğ‘‘d and/or kğ‘˜k constant and varying the value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Next, we examine the opposite scenario by fixing Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and varying dğ‘‘d and kğ‘˜k.

To measure the interpretability of the passive parameters at the active party, we use the function gâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”â‹…g(\cdot), where a higher value of gâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”â‹…g(\cdot) indicates lower interpretability. On the other hand, the privacy of the passive party is measured by the amount of MSE incurred by the active party in the case of an attack, with higher MSE values indicating greater privacy for the passive party.

In Figure 9, the PI trade-offs for the datasets bank and adult are illustrated for three different values of passive features. The orange-solid++ and blue-solidâˆ™âˆ™\bullet lines are the PI trade-offs obtained via the approaches in case i and case iv, respectively. It is worth to note two key aspects regarding the results. First, the inclusion of the results of case i is merely intended to provide a comparison with the more general PPS approach in case iv, and they are not applicable for datasets with k=2ğ‘˜2k=2. As seen from the figures, while the results of case i deviate quickly from those of case iv, they remain close to each other in the region of interest, which is approximately 0.18 and 0.14 for the bank and adult datasets, respectively, as indicated in Figure 4 (see the MSE obtained from half estimation). Furthermore, as the value of dğ‘‘d increases, the results from case i and case iv converge, as shown in the rightmost plots in Figure 9. Second, the preference for both the passive and active parties in terms of privacy and interpretability is that a small amount of perturbation in the passive parameters leads to a noticeable MSE resulted from inference attacks. This way, both parties meet their concerns with a minimal passive parameter perturbation. This is equivalent to having a concave PI trade-off curve. However, as observed from Figure 9 and the results throughout this section, the PI trade-off achieved by the proposed PPSs for different datasets and under different cases can sometimes be convex, sometimes concave, and in some cases, neither. It remains an open question whether the optimal PI trade-off curve in the region of interest follows a certain shape, preferably concave.

In Figure 10, the PI trade-off is demonstrated for the datasets bank, adult, satellite, and pendigits, when d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. To obtain the PI curve for the bank and adult datasets, we utilized the result from Remark (11), while for the remaining datasets, the optimization problem in (50) was solved. The approach in this case is considered more comprehensive as it does not impose any limitations on the mapping between the passive parameters and the parameters that the active party has given access to. Note that, as shown in Figure 4, the MSE for the half estimation on the satellite, bank, pendigits, and adult datasets is approximately 0.04, 0.17, 0.12, and 0.12, respectively. This leads to the observation that the PI curve below this MSE level for each of these datasets is almost linear. This observation is promising in the sense that the PPS is capable of delivering a balance between privacy and interpretability concerns of the parties, despite the general non-concave PI trade-off curve.

In Figure 11, the PI trade-off for case i and ii is depicted for the satellite and pendigits datasets. Itâ€™s important to keep in mind that in this instance, there is no widely accepted general solution that can serve as a benchmark for comparison. As a result, it remains a potential area of research to identify mappings from ğ–passubscriptğ–pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} to ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} that result in an improvement in the PI trade-off region.

In Figure 12, the effectiveness of the PPSs outlined in section V-B is compared to the baseline methods halfâˆ— and half estimation. Each plot in the figure corresponds to one of the datasets, with three different levels of interpretability depicted in each plot. For instance, in the top-left plot related to the satellite dataset, the interpretability levels are Ïµ=0.001,0.01,0.022italic-Ïµ0.0010.010.022\epsilon=0.001,0.01,0.022. Unlike Figures 9, 10, and 11, in this figure the performance of all four cases for PPS are evaluated against varying numbers of passive features with a fixed interpretability level in each curve. The results indicate that, for a fixed Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the gap between the MSE and that of halfâˆ— is not consistent. This is because as the number of passive parameters increases, finding the optimal solution for the system ğ€nâ€‹ğ—=ğ›â€²subscriptğ€ğ‘›ğ—superscriptğ›â€²\mathbf{A}_{n}\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime} becomes more challenging. For the satellite and pendigit datasets, the MSE does not seem to be affected as the value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon varies for the case of d=2ğ‘‘2d=2. However, as seen in the results in Figure 12 (MSE per feature of inference attack versus different values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for d=2ğ‘‘2d=2), the amount of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon required to produce a noticeable change in the MSE is not comparable to the other cases.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we examine the intricacies of a white-box VFL setting where two parties are involved in constructing a classifier collaboratively. The active party has access to the labels while the passive party contributes by sharing a separate set of features for the same samples. This collaboration takes place under the supervision of a third trusted entity known as the CA. Previous studies, such as those in [12, 11], have explored various inference attack methods that mainly rely on the active partyâ€™s exploitation of the confidence scores during the prediction phase. However, in this study, we delve into a novel approach of inference attack, which does not require the active party to have access to the targetâ€™s confidence score. The adversary uses their available training set, including labels and active party features, to construct a classifier that is then used to estimate the targetâ€™s confidence score. Once the estimation is obtained, the active party uses one of the previously studied inference attack methods to carry out the attack. This attack is referred to as â€œagnosticâ€ due to the absence of the targetâ€™s confidence score at the active party, which as a result puts all the samples used in the training phase at the risk of privacy exposure. Our findings show that the performance of the adversaryâ€™s model can be significantly enhanced by incorporating the confidence scores received from CA. This results in more accurate estimates of the targetâ€™s confidence score, which, in turn, can lead to more successful inference attacks. Since this type of attack does not rely on the availability of an attack targetâ€™s confidence score, it is therefore unaffected of any PPSs applied to the confidence scores, such as rounding or adding noise.

To counter the aforementioned potential for privacy breaches in a VFL setting, various privacy-preserving schemes (PPSs) have been proposed with a focus on protecting the passive parameters. To that end, we consider the development of PPSs that intentionally distort the passive parameters in a systematic manner. The active party is given access to these distorted parameters instead of the original versions. In designing these PPSs, we carefully consider the need for interpretability by the active party while still safeguarding the privacy of the passive party. This, in turn, gives rise to a trade-off between the interpretability of the VFL model for the active party and the privacy concerns of the passive party. Our approach moves away from a black or white viewpoint in VFL and instead aims to find a suitable balance between the needs of both parties to mitigate the risk of collaboration. Our goal is not to completely obscure the active party or completely protect the passive party, but rather to strike a balance between the two in order to minimize potential privacy risks.
